plain_language: Proving your disability is directly linked to something that happened during your military service. This is the foundation of any VA disability claim.
context: Without establishing service connection, you cannot receive disability compensation. The VA must agree that your condition is related to your military service before they'll pay benefits.
example: If you injured your back lifting equipment in basic training, that back pain is 'service-connected' because it happened during military service.

plain_language: A medical opinion letter from a doctor that connects your current disability to your military service. It's the bridge between your service records and your current condition.
context: Often the most important piece of evidence in a claim. Many claims are denied simply because they lack a nexus letter. The letter should use the phrase 'at least as likely as not' (50% probability or greater).
example: A doctor writes: 'It is my opinion that the veteran's current knee arthritis is at least as likely as not caused by the parachute injury documented in his service treatment records from 2005.'

plain_language: A standardized form the VA uses to evaluate disabilities. It contains specific questions and measurements that examiners fill out during your C&P exam.
context: There's a different DBQ for each type of condition. Understanding the DBQ for your condition helps you know exactly what the examiner is looking for and what information matters most.
example: The PTSD DBQ asks about nightmare frequency, avoidance behaviors, and how symptoms affect your work and relationships. The knee DBQ measures range of motion in degrees.

plain_language: The date from which the VA will start paying you benefits. This determines how much back pay you receive.
context: Generally, the effective date is when you filed your claim (or Intent to File). Filing earlier means more back pay if approved. This is why Intent to File is so important.
example: If you filed an Intent to File on January 1, 2025, then filed your full claim in March 2025 and got approved in September 2025, your effective date would be January 1, 2025, and you'd receive back pay from that date.

plain_language: A condition the VA automatically assumes is service-connected if you served in certain locations or time periods. No need to prove the connection.
context: Presumptive conditions make claims easier because you don't need a nexus letter. The VA presumes the service connection based on your service location or era (Vietnam, Gulf War, burn pits, etc.).
example: Type 2 diabetes is presumptive for Vietnam veterans exposed to Agent Orange. If you served in Vietnam and have Type 2 diabetes, the VA presumes it's service-connected without requiring additional proof.

plain_language: Compensation and Pension Exam - a medical examination the VA orders to evaluate your disability. The results heavily influence your rating decision.
context: About 93% of C&P exams are done by contractors, not VA employees. The exam typically lasts 15-30 minutes. What happens during this exam can make or break your claim.
example: After filing a claim for PTSD, the VA schedules a C&P exam where a psychologist asks about your symptoms, their frequency, and how they affect your daily life and work.

plain_language: How far you can move a joint, measured in degrees. This is a key measurement for musculoskeletal conditions like back, knee, and shoulder problems.
context: ROM directly determines your rating percentage for many conditions. STOP at the point of pain during testing - if you push through pain, the examiner will record full ROM and you'll get a lower rating.
example: Normal knee flexion is 140 degrees. If pain limits you to 45 degrees, that's a 10% rating. If you push through pain to 60 degrees, you get 0% because it's considered 'full' ROM.

plain_language: What you can't do because of your disability - the real-world impact on your daily life, work, and activities.
context: Examiners must document functional limitations, not just symptoms. Explaining what you CAN'T do is often more important than describing pain levels.
example: Instead of saying 'my back hurts,' say 'I can't lift more than 10 pounds, can't stand for more than 15 minutes, and can't sit through a movie without getting up to stretch.'

plain_language: A period when your symptoms are significantly worse than usual. These 'bad days' are important for your rating.
context: Examiners must ask about flare-ups and estimate how they affect your function. Don't just describe your average day - describe your WORST days, as these count for your rating.
example: Your knee normally hurts at a 4/10, but during flare-ups (2-3 times per month), pain is 8/10 and you can barely walk. The examiner should document this and estimate ROM during flare-ups.

plain_language: A notice to the VA that you plan to file a claim. It 'saves' your effective date for up to one year while you gather evidence.
context: Filing an ITF immediately protects your effective date. You then have 12 months to submit your full claim. This can mean thousands of dollars in additional back pay.
example: You decide to file for PTSD but don't have all your evidence yet. File an ITF today, then take 6 months to get buddy statements and a nexus letter. Your effective date is still today, not 6 months from now.

plain_language: The process where the VA gathers evidence for your claim - requesting records, ordering exams, and getting medical opinions.
context: After you file, the VA 'develops' your claim by getting service records, VA treatment records, and scheduling C&P exams. You can help by submitting your own evidence.
example: During development, the VA might request your service treatment records from the National Archives, your VA medical center records, and schedule a C&P exam with a contract examiner.

plain_language: The VA's legal obligation to help you gather evidence for your claim. They must make reasonable efforts to get records and schedule necessary exams.
context: The VA is supposed to help you, not work against you. If they fail in their duty to assist (like not requesting records you told them about), this can be grounds for appeal.
example: You tell the VA you were treated at a specific hospital after service. The VA has a duty to request those records. If they decide your claim without trying to get those records, they've failed their duty to assist.

plain_language: Organizations like the American Legion, VFW, and DAV that provide FREE help with VA claims. They can represent you throughout the process.
context: VSOs are trained in VA claims and can help you avoid mistakes. They're free and can access your VA files. Having a VSO significantly improves your chances of success.
example: Before filing your claim, you visit the local DAV office. A trained representative reviews your case, helps you complete forms, identifies conditions you might have missed, and represents you if you need to appeal.

plain_language: A percentage (0-100%) that represents how much your service-connected disability affects your ability to work. Higher percentage means higher monthly payment.
context: Ratings go in increments of 10% (0, 10, 20, 30... up to 100%). Each rating level has specific criteria you must meet. Rating decisions can be appealed if you disagree.
example: A 70% PTSD rating means 'occupational and social impairment with deficiencies in most areas.' A 50% rating means 'reduced reliability and productivity.' Each level has specific symptom criteria.

plain_language: When you have multiple disabilities, the VA combines them using a special formula - NOT by simple addition. This determines your total rating.
context: The VA uses a 'combined ratings table' that accounts for the fact that multiple disabilities can't each reduce your function independently. The math is in your favor for lower ratings, against you for higher ones.
example: A 50% rating plus a 30% rating doesn't equal 80%. Using the VA formula: 50% + 30% of remaining 50% = 50% + 15% = 65%, which rounds to 70%.

plain_language: An extra 10% added to your combined rating when you have the same type of disability affecting both sides of your body (both knees, both arms, etc.).
context: The bilateral factor recognizes that having disabilities on both sides makes daily function harder. It's applied before your combined rating is calculated.
example: If you have 20% for left knee arthritis and 10% for right knee arthritis, the VA combines those (28%), adds 10% bilateral factor (28 x 1.1 = 30.8), then combines with your other ratings.

plain_language: Medical records from when you were in the military. These document injuries, illnesses, and treatments during your service.
context: STRs are critical evidence. They prove something happened during service. If your STRs document an injury, it's much easier to prove service connection.
example: Your STRs show you went to sick call for back pain after a training accident in 2008. This documentation makes it much easier to service-connect your current back condition.

plain_language: Non-medical evidence from you or others about your symptoms and how they affect you. This includes your own statements and buddy statements.
context: The VA must consider lay evidence. You are competent to describe your own symptoms, pain, and limitations. Don't think only medical evidence matters - your own statements are evidence too.
example: A statement describing how your PTSD symptoms have changed over time, how often you have nightmares, and how your marriage has suffered.

plain_language: A written statement from someone who knows about your condition - a fellow service member, family member, coworker, or friend who has witnessed your symptoms.
context: Buddy statements are powerful evidence, especially when medical records are incomplete. They can verify in-service events or describe current symptoms.
example: A fellow soldier writes: 'I served with SGT Smith in Iraq in 2007. On March 15, 2007, I witnessed him injure his back when our vehicle struck an IED.'

plain_language: The connection or link between your current disability and your military service. Proving nexus is often the hardest part of a VA claim.
context: Service connection requires: (1) current disability, (2) in-service event/injury, and (3) NEXUS between them. A nexus letter from a doctor is the most common way to prove this link.
example: Your nexus for knee arthritis: You injured your knee in the Army (in-service event), you have current knee arthritis (current disability), and a doctor says the arthritis is related to the old injury (nexus).

plain_language: When your disability was directly caused by something that happened during your military service - an injury, illness, or event while you were in.
context: This is the most straightforward type of service connection. You need evidence of an in-service event and a medical link (nexus) to your current condition.
example: You broke your ankle during a training exercise (documented in STRs), and now you have ankle arthritis. A doctor links the current arthritis to the old fracture.

plain_language: When a NEW disability is caused or made worse by a condition you're ALREADY service-connected for.
context: Secondary claims are often easier because you already have service connection for the primary condition. Many veterans miss secondary conditions they could claim.
example: You're service-connected for a knee injury. The knee problem causes you to limp, which leads to hip pain. The hip condition is 'secondary' to the knee.

plain_language: When military service made an existing condition permanently worse. Even if you had the condition before service, you can be compensated for the worsening.
context: If you had a condition before service and it got worse during service, you may be entitled to compensation for the degree of worsening.
example: You had mild asthma before joining. After exposure to burn pits, your asthma became severe. The VA can rate you for the aggravation (worsening) caused by service.

plain_language: The main form to file for VA disability compensation. This is where you list all the conditions you're claiming.
context: This is the form that starts your disability claim. You can file it online at VA.gov (fastest), by mail, or in person.
example: On VA Form 21-526EZ, you list: PTSD (direct), back condition (direct), right knee pain (direct), left hip pain (secondary to right knee).

plain_language: The form to reopen a denied claim when you have NEW and RELEVANT evidence the VA hasn't seen before.
context: If your claim was denied, you can file this form with new evidence to get a new decision. Average processing: ~93 days.
example: Your PTSD claim was denied because you didn't have a nexus letter. You obtain one from a doctor, then file a Supplemental Claim to reopen.

plain_language: An appeal asking a senior VA employee to look at your claim again using the SAME evidence. Best when you believe the VA made an error.
context: No new evidence allowed. Use when the VA ignored evidence, used wrong rating criteria, or made calculation errors.
example: The decision ignored a nexus letter in your file. File a Higher-Level Review and explain: 'The decision ignored the nexus letter from Dr. Smith dated 5/15/2024.'

plain_language: An appeal to have a Veterans Law Judge review your case. Longest option but you can present your case at a hearing.
context: Choose from three lanes: Direct Review, Evidence Submission (90 days to submit evidence), or Hearing Request.
example: After a Higher-Level Review is denied, you file a Board Appeal and request a hearing with a Veterans Law Judge.

plain_language: The VA's internal appeals 'court' where Veterans Law Judges review appeals. Board decisions carry more weight than regional office decisions.
context: If the Board grants your appeal, it's very rare for it to be reversed. If denied, you can appeal to federal court.
example: The regional office denied your claim twice, so you appeal to the BVA. A Veterans Law Judge reviews your case and grants service connection.

plain_language: When the VA sends your claim back for additional work because something was done wrong or more information is needed. Often leads to approval.
context: A remand isn't a denial - it means the reviewer found problems. Your claim goes back for correction, which often results in approval.
example: The Board finds your C&P exam didn't address flare-ups. They remand for a new exam. After the new exam, your claim is approved.

plain_language: A claim where you submit ALL your evidence upfront, rather than waiting for the VA to gather it. Results in faster processing.
context: With an FDC, you're saying 'I've given you everything - decide now.' This can cut processing time significantly.
example: Instead of waiting months for VA to request records, you gather everything yourself: STRs, medical records, buddy statements, and nexus letter. Then file as a Fully Developed Claim.
